commentText: This movie is only outmatched in sheer badness by the sanctimoniousness of Kirk Cameron.

In case you're wondering, this isn't even watchable as a "good bad" movie. PROS: Laughably tries to justify brainless Christmas materialism denies that Christianity co-opted Pagan traditions. Writing for token black character is offensively bad and at times verges on entertaining. 'Actor' who plays Kirk Cameron's sister looks like a meth addict. Santa is portrayed as both violent and rapey. CONS: Ssssssssllllllllloooooowwwwww...some characters, especially the Jewwy-looking guy who plays Kirk Cameron's brother-in-law, deliver their lines with long, unnecessary pauses between words. I suspect this is to pad the run time. Most of movie takes place in a stationary vehicle.

replies.commentText: +RobbyRaccoon Here's two other pros for you: - A psychotic Santa beating the shit out of people with dubstep music in the background and even when he's supposed to be jolly, he got crazy eyes. - The scene with the two guys talking conspiracy theories behind their empty cups. It's so weird and so amateurish that you start picking it apart piece by piece. It also comes completely out of nowhere and is never mentioned again.

Despite the horrible movie and Kirk Cameron's failed attempt to save Christmas, I just want to educate the dummies who say Jesus has nothing to do with Christmas. Well the holiday has the word "Christ," so to say that it has nothing to do with Jesus is ridiculous and you guys lack knowledge in history. Yes! I do understand that before Christianity dominated Europe, pegan holidays and rituals were observed during the times of the winter solstice. But when Christianity came about the celebrations were abolished (like Saturnalia and Yule) and by the 3rd century the Church established that Dec 25 is the feast of the Nativity of Christ (Christ Mass) translated later to Christmas. Look I know you guys have a hate for religion, but to bury real history to argue your viewpoints is the definition of bigotry and ignorance.

lol atheists saying Jesus was not born on December 25th and that Christmas is a "pagan" holiday as if these are original criticisms that have not been addressed ad nauseum. When you only stick to your lib/atheist propaganda books, shows, etc where these claims are constantly reiterated, I guess you start to believe they are valid. However, nobody claimed Jesus was definitely born on December 25. It's unknown exactly why this date was chosen. One theory is that The Annunciation (Mary being told of her pregnancy with Jesus) took place on March 25 so his birth would be around December 25. Another theory is that December 25 was chosen to counteract pagan celebrations around this time. Still others suggest it was chosen around this time because it was Winter, days were shorter and thus people had more time for celebration, festivals, etc. That so-called "pagan" traditions (Christmas Tree, Yule Log) may have infiltrated Christmas is irrelevant because the point of Christmas remains to celebrate Christ. It's like saying because the USA observes Mexican traditions, like Cinco de Mayo, the USA is really Mexican. In fact, the term "Christmas" comes from & means "Christ Mass."

Should Christians Observe Holidays? The question of observing holidays is addressed in God’s word. After all, many early Christians had recently departed their Jewish faith. What were they to do with the many holidays that their friends and family still observed? Some chose to make a complete separation from their past traditions, others put those customs to use. “Who are you to judge another's servant? To his own master he stands or falls. Indeed, he will be made to stand, for God is able to make him stand. One person esteems one day above another; another esteems every day alike. Let each be fully convinced in his own mind. He who observes the day, observes it to the Lord; and he who does not observe the day, to the Lord he does not observe it. He who eats, eats to the Lord, for he gives God thanks; and he who does not eat, to the Lord he does not eat, and gives God thanks. For none of us lives to himself, and no one dies to himself. For if we live, we live to the Lord; and if we die, we die to the Lord. Therefore, whether we live or die, we are the Lord's” (Romans 14:4-8). Paul’s words are puzzling to those who know how forcefully Paul argued against bringing Jewish customs into the church. However, recall that Paul observed Jewish customs at times. In Acts 21:20-26 you can read were Paul complied with the ordinances for purification even though the law of Moses was no longer in effect. Paul explains this in I Corinthians 9:19-22, “For though I am free from all men, I have made myself a servant to all, that I might win the more; and to the Jews I became as a Jew, that I might win Jews; to those who are under the law, as under the law, that I might win those who are under the law; to those who are without law, as without law (not being without law toward God, but under law toward Christ), that I might win those who are without law; to the weak I became as weak, that I might win the weak. I have become all things to all men, that I might by all means save some.” Paul’s goal was to teach people about Christ, yet the people he approached all have personal biases and expectations of what constitutes religious practice. So long as those practices did not violate what a Christian must do, Paul was willing to personally conform himself to those expectations in order to have opportunity to teach people. He strongly stated that it was wrong to bind these foreign practices on the church, but as an individual he had some liberty. In other words, if a Jew came out of Judaism and desired to continue to celebrate Passover with his family, such was not wrong as an individual. As a Christian he knows that the requirement for observing Passover had ended when Jesus died on the cross (Colossians 2:14). Thus to him it is not a religious feast, but a secular one. Yet, by keeping it he is accepted in the Jewish community and has opportunities to teach about Christ. The actual keeping of the feast does not violate any command of Christ. Another Jew coming into Christianity enjoys the freedom that it provides and decides to make a complete break from Judaism. He chooses to not to follow any of the past customs. Should he look down at his fellow Christian who is still observing some of the Jewish customs? “But why do you judge your brother? Or why do you show contempt for your brother? For we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ. For it is written: "As I live, says the LORD, Every knee shall bow to Me, And every tongue shall confess to God." So then each of us shall give account of himself to God.” (Romans 14:10-12). I’m sure that some ex-Jews had a difficult time eating pork after a lifetime of avoiding it. But the truth is that it doesn’t matter if a person, as an individual, decides not eat ham. “I know and am convinced by the Lord Jesus that there is nothing unclean of itself; but to him who considers anything to be unclean, to him it is unclean” (Romans 14:14). Should then, the person who chooses to follow his old customs look down on his fellow Christian who does not do so? “So let no one judge you in food or in drink, or regarding a festival or a new moon or sabbaths, which are a shadow of things to come, but the substance is of Christ” (Colossians 2:16-17). It is a two-way street. “Let not him who eats despise him who does not eat, and let not him who does not eat judge him who eats; for God has received him” (Romans 14:3). The key is the fact that neither person is violating the laws of God. “Do you have faith? Have it to yourself before God. Happy is he who does not condemn himself in what he approves” (Romans 14:22). But such liberty in individual choice does not translate into new laws for the church. While an ex-Jew might choose not eat pork, he cannot bind on all Christians a ban from pork. “For every creature of God is good, and nothing is to be refused if it is received with thanksgiving” (I Timothy 4:4). A person who decides to enter a synagogue and join in the Sabbath observance cannot tell other Christians that they must observe the Sabbath as well. Therefore, we reach the point where we need to ask, can Christians observe secular holidays? Many brethren observe the Fourth of July, Memorial Day, and Mother’s Day without a second thought as to whether they are right or wrong. These days are merely days set aside to enjoy special occasions. But like the old Jewish customs, it would be wrong to bring these secular holidays into the church. For example, Mother’s Day is slowly being pulled into the denominations and becoming a part of their religious practices. If I chose to remember my mother on a particular day of the year, that is my business, but I cannot create a special day for the church to remember mothers because God did not authorize it. But what about Christmas? It began in idolatry and false religious practice, so how can a Christian participate in it? The question is: does it continue to be viewed as idolatry? As an example, the days of our week are named after false gods. Should Christians not use those names because of their connection to idolatry? No, because no one makes the connection these days. To make an appointment on Tuesday doesn’t cause anyone to assume that you are a pagan. The fact that Christmas originated in pagan and false religious practice ought to make us pause and consider. But the same question needs to be asked: does my participating in the celebration cause others to make the wrong conclusion about my beliefs? I doubt anyone today would conclude that those celebrating Christmas are pagan idolaters. However, since Christmas and Easter are recognized as religious holidays, some observing us may think we are also keeping these holidays as a religious requirement. This could be a cause of concern. So, consider this: when you see decorative lights on a house, do you assume the owners are celebrating Christmas as a religious holiday? I think most would honestly say, “No.” I know atheist and Jews who put up decorated trees and give out gifts. Thus Christmas is no longer strongly associated with Christianity. In fact, those in denominations are complaining that Christmas has lost its religious significance. That is why so many are chanting slogans, such as “Put Christ back into Christmas.” When people ask me what I’m doing to celebrate Easter at the congregation, I say, “The same thing we do every Sunday.” The puzzled looks give me an opportunity to show them the passages proving that Christ’s death is to be remembered every Sunday. Yet, we still decorate our home with pastel items and hide brightly colored eggs for the children. Nothing religious is connected with Easter in our home, but as a social custom we enjoy the holiday. We are able to enjoy Christmas as well without turning it into a religious holiday. I don’t have stars on my tree or a nativity scene in my yard. I can sing carols, but I skip the ones that speak of Bethlehem, angels, mangers, wise men, holy nights, and shepherds. I leave religion out of my holidays because God did not authorize them, but it doesn’t mean I must cross the holidays off my calendar. What about my brothers who strongly object to certain holiday observances? “Therefore let us not judge one another anymore, but rather resolve this, not to put a stumbling block or a cause to fall in our brother's way” (Romans 14:13). I’m going to try my best not to cause offense. If I know someone objects to Christmas, I’m not going to invite them over for a turkey dinner on December 25th. There are plenty of other occasions to get together without my making things awkward for them. The instructions found in Romans 14 are often misapplied to situations they were never intended. But we mustn’t forget to learn and use those laws in their proper context.

There is no war on Christmas, I love Christmas regardless of the fact that I do NOT believe in ANY deity. I love the music (even the religious songs), the food, and the presence of family, as I grew up a Christian. I have no problem with the term "Merry Christmas" I say it every year. However, I also say "Happy Holidays" to people I don't know personally, because they may be of another tradition( there are many winter season holidays) and I live in America where many traditions take place. Saying "Happy Holidays" is not an attack on Christmas, it is respect for those of other traditions. I don't understand why this is so hard to understand. However, I have studied the history of how these "Christmas" stories came about. Jesus's Birthday Despite Christmas being associated with the birth of Jesus Christ, there is no biblical passage or other evidence establishing Jesus's date of birth. In early-to-mid 4th century, The Western Christian Church set the date of Christmas to December 25 as a means to rival existing solstice celebrations, and was later also adopted in the East. While there is no established date for the birth of Jesus, the following passage from Luke 2:8-12[3] seem to suggest that he was born during the lambing season: "And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.”" Natalis Invicti Natalis Invicti ("birthday of the unconquered one") was a festival celebrating the rebirth of the sun, Sol Invictus ("Invincible Sun"), the official sun god of the Roman Empire. Scholars argue that the festival was placed on the date of the winter solstice as the sun would seemingly reverse its retreat and thereby prove itself unconquered. Early Christian writers connected the rebirth of the sun with the birth of Jesus Christ, and the festival is believed to be responsible for the date of Christmas. Saturnalia Saturnalia is an ancient Roman celebration of Saturn, the youngest of the Titans and father of the gods in Roman and Greek mythology. While originally only celebrated for a day, it grew to a week-long celebration starting at December 17 and ending at December 23. Besides the public rites involved in the festival, there were also a series of holidays and customs celebrated privately. The celebrations included a school holiday, gift-giving and a special market. Yule Yule is a winter festival taking place on December 25, and was initially celebrated by the Germanic people as a pagan religious festival. The festival was later absorbed into the Christian festival of Christmas. Customs such as the Yule log, the Yule goat, the Christmas ham, wassailing etc. all come from Yule. Controversies War on Christmas The term War on Christmas gained traction in the early 2000s, thanks to conservative commentators such as Fox News's Bill O'Reilly. The term is used to denote the alleged censorship of Christmas, and how the use of terms and phrases such as Xmas and Happy Holidays are, as Fox News host John Gibson puts it, a "liberal plot to ban the sacred Christmas holiday". Scientist and former White House senior policy analyst Jeff Schweitzer stated that "there is no war", and "Christians like Bill O'Reilly have declared war on religious freedom, demanding that the United States convert to a Christian nation", referring to their insistence that stores and the like should use language which is explicitly Christian.

"'Happy Holidays' or 'Seasons Greetings'. . . whatever that means. . ." Well, I can see how this may be confusing, but let's take this as a question of semantics. "Happy" or "Greetings" (in this context) are commonly used lexical units to wish well to individuals and/or express an amicably-natured salutation, ex: "Happy Birthday, Chuck!" or "Greetings from Chicago". "Holiday" can be seen as an umbrella term for any day that celebrates an event, idea, deity, etc and that is given special status by/in a state, country, town, religion, culture, etc., which are often based off recorded history, cultural/religious memory, etc. and differ according to region, religion, etc.; for specific examples of "Holidays" see Wikipedia or anyone you know who is familiar with this concept. "Happy Holidays" is used by one individual to express well-wishing, joyousness and sheer merriment to another individual on a non-specific level, based off the presumption that the receiver will celebrate/celebrates any of a number of days which would be classified as a "Holiday" at the given time of year. "Season" denotes a stretch of time varying in length, but in this case specifically refers (at least in some Western cultures) to a brief period of time (sp. December/January) where several holidays (see above definition) are being actively celebrated by people in the area, community, etc. The phrase "Seasons Greetings" is a not uncommon way of recognizing that enough people celebrate any one or more of the holidays celebrated at this often festive time of year for it not to be a weird thing to say. These phrases exist because people come from different backgrounds and celebrate different things and have different ideologies and therefore it should not be assumed that everyone is on the same page when it comes to who celebrates what and why. This from a polyglot. (For the record, this was just a sarcastic rant, not something prepared for scholarly criticism.) :)

I believe that Christmas is a combination of religious symbolism and pagan symbolism. Many traditions like mistletoe or a Christmas tree are traditions passed down over generations that aren't related to Christ's birth. Other religious symbols, like the Nativity scene, or certain carols like "O Holy Night", "What Child Is This?", and "Away in a Manger" have been passed down over generations and can be credited to Christianity. This means that for Christians in America, we get to celebrate Christmas in the way that it was intended for us, centered around Christ's birth and giving of ourselves. I agree that we as Christians should start giving back more on Christmas rather than making our Christmas lists and shopping too much. This year I started doing that by helping the homeless on Christmas Day. Atheists are free to celebrate Christmas too, for what it means to them. Hanging lights on their house, decorating a Christmas tree, hanging stockings, spending time with family... They are still free to enjoy their traditions as well. We should stop arguing over "who stole Christmas from who" and "if it's really religious or not". I say we all just enjoy this time of year, whether you are religious or not, and we spend time giving of ourselves and enjoying time with family in peace and harmony. We should just enjoy the season in peace instead of fighting over who owns the holiday. Believe what you believe, do traditions with your family, and let others do the same, even if you disagree. This is the best time of the year where we get to be thankful for everything we have. Christians: We can be thankful that we even get to celebrate Christ's birth in America. Atheists: You get to be thankful that you have freedom to practice your traditions as well. Peace be with you all this holiday season.

What the four-eye says is actually true. Basically nothing in Christmas has anything at all to do with the Bible. Its origins are pagan (do a bit of research on the origin of Christmas and how it was introduced into Christianity), and none of the traditions and symbolism is biblical, but much of it is taken from pagan cultures. Christmas is like a mish-mash of pagan traditions (many of which go blatantly against what the Bible commands). Moreover, there isn't even one single example of the followers of Jesus celebrating his birth or commanding others to do so. (Of course from a scholarly point of view the entire narrative of Jesus' birth is most probably completely fictional, invented and written down almost 100 years after it allegedly happened, but that's an entire topic in itself.) "Put Christ back in Christmas" is quite a misnomer because Christ has never been in Christmas. Personally I'd recommend doing the exact opposite: Remove "Christ" from Christmas. Excise all religious baggage from it, and celebrate it for what it is: A joyous occasion of family reunion, socialization, gift-giving and appreciation.

+Jew2sexy Actually, the idea of gift giving on Christmas was due to Bishop Nicholas (ordained St. Nicholas), who would leave small gifts in the empty shoes of needy children in the Greek city of Myra in the early 300s AD. He was born to a wealthy family, but sold all of his riches and gave money/gifts to the poor. His tradition carried on for centuries and he transformed into Santa Claus. It's certainly true that Christmas, today, has changed a great deal. However, it's still a time for family, for recognizing/worshiping Jesus, and definitely still a time for charitable giving. Btw, if you want to read an interesting article about Christ's true birth date, check this out: http://www.biblicalarchaeology.org/daily/biblical-topics/new-testament/how-december-25-became-christmas/ Very cool and eye-opening information.

+SuperDelusionist While it may be true that there aren't any solid evidence - what "solid" even means is debatable here - that Jesus existed, it still is not out of the plane of possibility that he did exist as a crazed fool claiming to be the son of god. besides, we have crazed fools claiming to be the son of god all the time. Heck, I think there were already a handful since the turn of the century alone. So, it is the reasonable position to reserve judgement and allow for the possibility than to outright negate it and assert positively that he never existed. When you assert in the positive that he did not exist - yes, that's an assertion. Even a negation is an assertion - it is up to you to provide evidence since you are making the positive claim. The burden of proof does not fall on the one reserving judgement and making no claim either way. I understand a few people google a few fallacies and think they are Bertrand Russell, but logic is much more involved than a few fallacies, but I digress. I personally don't feel that he did exist even as a man by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, but I would never make the positive assertion that he did not exist or that some nut thinking he was the son of god existed since there are at least a handful alive today. It's probably a moot point anyway. I think what we must argue here is whether or not the son of god or god existed, never mind a crazy man, because crazy men have existed, do exist, and always will exist. The question is whether or not some crazy man had dealings with god, and that is a claim the needs extraordinary evidence. That's the claim that is absurd. If someone says, "do you think Jesus existed." I say, "surely some man named Jesus existed but was he the chosen son of god capable of miracles, and to that I say, 'absolutely not.' There is no evidence for gods yet much to contradict the existence of a god so there would be no reason to suppose a "chosen son" of a god. If and when you can show the existence of a god, we can then debate the validity of a chosen son of god. Until that time, while there may have well been a crazed man named Jesus, there is no reason to suppose he was as he claimed."

+Michael Tackett I say this: Jesus MAY have existed, but he was surely not divine nor is there any evidence to support the claim that he actually ever existed. Same thing for god, i say: There may be a god, but there is no evidence to support the claim.

commentText: Re-writing history for money, you're a cunt Kirk Cameron.

Talk about an F Grade Vince Vaughn character... And for those asking 'if its not about Christ, why is it CHRISTmas?' Simple. The catholics celebrate masses, so they called it Christ Mass or Christmas as it has become known. They could have named it Super Jesus Awesome Fun Day if they felt froggy. The name is irrelevant, its just a brand.

Luke 2:1-20New International Version (NIV) The Birth of Jesus 2 In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. 2 (This was the first census that took place while[a] Quirinius was governor of Syria.) 3 And everyone went to their own town to register. 4 So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. 5 He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. 6 While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, 7 and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them. 8 And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night. 9 An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. 10 But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. 11 Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. 12 This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” 13 Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, 14 “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favor rests.” 15 When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” 16 So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. 17 When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, 18 and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. 19 But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. 20 The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.

Teeeeeeeeeeeechnically CHRISTmas IS about Christ. There are dissenting ideas about why the date was chosen (e.g., some say that it has to do with a belief that the conception happened 9 months earlier) since it is not believed he was born in December (I think currently there is some evidence he was born in April? but don't quote me on that one). The celebrating of Christmas started in the 4th century when Christianity was made the official state belief of the Roman Empire (after years of Christian persecution). Because it was no longer being persecuted this is when Christianity started to flourish and they started to really define their beliefs, and also started to celebrate the birth of Christ. Through time the various already established traditions surrounding the winter equinox, etc started to attach themselves to the holiday. So everything you said about the origins of the tree and yule log and all that are accurate, but the word Christmas is to celebrate the birth of Christ. I do agree the best way to celebrate it, whatever you celebrate it for, is by helping your fellow man though, since to me the holiday is all about the spirit of giving! Source: I like learning shit, and I'm currently taking a World Religions course. LOL

I think we're all talking past each other. We skeptics are framing the argument wrong. What we should be saying is that the traditions observed at Christmas have nothing to do with Jesus, because they're pagan in origin, but like any other celebration, the event itself has all the meaning the people observing it are willing to give it. On the other hand, Christians are not engaging us on the argument we're intending to make. Saying "Christmas is about Christ because it's in the name" does nothing to disprove the pagan origin of the date and the traditions - that's pretty much impossible, unless you somehow manage to find actual evidence to the contrary. The name itself isn't evidence, it's just a name, likely given in an attempt to christianise Yule, thus making it easier to convert Europeans - it's much easier to convince people to change their religion if the new religion's celebrations are basically the ones they've been observing anyway. So, in closing: Christians, your holiday is about whatever you want it to be about - just be aware that the traditions aren't Christian in origin. However, don't insist on other people observing it the same way as you do. Let people say "Happy Holidays" or "Season's Greetings", because some of us want to still celebrate the winter solstice in any number of ways (or at least be polite when someone wishes us "Merry Christmas"). And don't be upset when people put up their own displays that don't show the nativity scene - they're just celebrating their own holiday. Show some tolerance, please.

+Kirra Sebastian"the winter solstice is one of the christmas traditions..." "plus, eighty percent of the world doesn't get a white Christmas." ----- Uhm, how old are you actually? Don't tell me you're serious... The holiday of December 25th originated as a Pagan winter solstice, later reformed by Rome as the Saturnalia. The Saturnalia celebrated the rebirth of the sun god as Saturn. It was further celebrated under the title Yule in various other locations in Europe. In 350 CE, the Pope claimed the Saturnalia as a Christian observance.

You're allowed to believe whatever you believe, and you're allowed to state your opinion; it's the forcing of opinions that is fucking unacceptable. God isn't exactly something that can either be proved or unproved--at least at this point, and as such, people should be allowed to believe whatever the hell they want, as long as their opinion isn't shoved down the throats of their fellow man. +The Gamer You're right, they are different. One is done, within the person's own thoughts, with the hint of love and the spreading of one's love. The other is done out of spite and hatred. Look man, I'm an agnostic, and never in my life have I attended church regularly, nor had the intention to. But, by those intentions, I have never once felt like I knew what was best for others, or for mankind as a whole, nor would I ever claim to understand concepts beyond my knowledge; like the effects of a Godless world, whether they be for good or bad. Predictions made upon the future events while trapped in the confines of current life are, well, ignorant by their very nature. I'm just saying, whether you're a believer or not, it should be okay, and more so, common practice to know and understand that we may not know, at all, what is best for our neighbors upon this shit heap we've found ourselves, and that as such, we should not proclaim what is best for each other. Be accepting, not damning of each other's beliefs.

+The Gamer You are correct, but then again, who in Christianity identifies with the Westboro Baptist Church? Which I know is not what you're trying to say, but there is a mistake that some people make, wherein they lump all of Christianity in with the imbeciles in Westboro; as if Christianity at its core pleaded its members to cruelty, and yes, that is in there on occasion, but it is not the main message, it is not the main goal. It would be equatable to lumping all of Islam into Islamic extremists; which, obviously, is wrong. I think we're on the same page here. Look, I disagree with the people who claim that people are 'committing war upon Christmas,' and likewise, I disagree with Kirk Cameron here. Nobody intends to erase Christmas, in fact, you could make the argument that Christmas is longer and more ingrained into American society now than it has ever been. What the folks who, like Kirk Cameron, fail to realize is that although we're attempting to be more sensitive to people of other religions, or of no religion at all is that nobody is trying to erase Christmas, we're just making room for a more culturally diverse world, and America. Which is a good thing. But to them, obviously, it isn''t. That being said, all Christians, obviously, don't believe this, just a few bad eggs in a bigger basket.

commentText: This guy is an idiot. The Christian Jesus myth has no real merit. It only gained fame because the Roman Emperor Constantine forced it on everyone in his empire. There is much better evidence for the existence of Santa Claus than there is for Jesus existing. By the way, Easter is named for a Sumerian Goddess of fertility and her name was Ishtar and it is pronounced, Easter. The Romans and the Christian church hijacked all the pagan celebrations and give them some Christian bull shit twist. For instance Candlemass, or Groundhogs day is from the Pagan celebration of Imbolc and the Goddess Brigid and the coming of spring and the strengthening of the Sun God who was born at Yule, he is born on the winter solstice every year. Saint Valentines day is from the Roman Pagan practice of Lupercalia, check that one out sometime, it looked bizarre and fun, but not for dogs and goats though. Saint John's day is the summer solstice when the Sun God is at his peak power. Lammas or Loaf Mass is from the Pagan Celtic Lughnassadh, where the Sun God is sacrificed for the beginning of the harvest. He is sacrificed every year and reborn again at yule the Winter Solstice every year. Of course the 23.5 degree tilt of the earth in our orbit around the Sun cause this but it is fun to celebrate the Earth's journey with these celebrations. The point is, Christianity is a huge lie. Since Jesus and Mary also figure into the Koran, it too is another huge lie. Ask me for my proof of Santa, it is a fantastic and true story.

I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. 11 Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. 12 This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” 13 Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, 14 “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favor rests.” 15 When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” 16 So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. 17 When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, 18 and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. 19 But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. 20 The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.

Murdock, who has made an astro-theological connection between most religions from the era and region. +HConstantine I'm sure Bayesian analysis has its place. It's just that it has nothing to do with determining the historical existence of Jesus. In a review of his two volume set, about the Historicity of Jesus, the first book dedicated to introducing the Bayesian method in language approachable by the average non-academic intellect, and the second dedicated to an analysis of what scant and weak evidence there is for the historicity of Jesus, reviewers, including the author of the article, as well as commenters seem to be in basic agreement... Not with you, but with each other. They felt like the Bayesian method was being degraded by being applied to something as controversial as Jesus studies, immediately upon introducing it as the best method for producing historical accuracy. They all agree that the Bayesian method is the best approach, but that it should have been demonstrated by some historical data which was far less controversial, and, in many way, easier to prove via the Bayesian method. Thus building and gaining confidence in the method before tackling such a controversial and emotive issue. I am drawing this from the article and comment section at the following link: http://lesswrong.com/lw/9pm/minireview_proving_history_bayes_theorem_and_the/ I was in search of reasons not to use Bayes theorem as a methodology for proving history. Instead, what I got was why it shouldn't be used relative to the historical Jesus (yet). My search criterion was this: "problems with applying Bayes theorem to historical research" , and that article was one of two at the top of the search results, both from the same source/web site. The one at the top of the search results was this one: http://lesswrong.com/lw/774/a_history_of_bayes_theorem/ Which is more of a summary of information contained in another book about Bayes theorem, by a different author. I am now quite confident that Bayes theorem would be extremely useful in analysis of historical data, and even with regard to something as controversial as the historicity of Jesus. Especially since the complaints weren't that it wouldn't work for that, but that doing so early on would tend to raise the ire of a lot of emotional historians who are quite attached to their favorite religious beliefs, causing them to dismiss the theorem as probable... Much as you have done here. I guess they had a point. My suggestion is that if you wish to be taken seriously as an investigator of any kind, you should divorce yourself of your emotional attachments to pet theories.

+Palmela Handerson Equating oral tradition to a game of telephone is just inaccurate. It's identical. Oral tradition IS a game of telephone, in a very literal sense. Oral tradition is not the same as a game in which people intentionally change a message to make it funny. That's not how the game is played. The game is played, for one, to demonstrate that the message does change from person to person, and in some cases the result can be quite hilarious. Each successive person is supposed to relay the information as reliably and accurately as they can. However, because of the ways in which our brains work, everyone invariably hears, or else places emphasis on different parts, and makes various associations which may or may not be relevant to the information being conveyed. What the Hell did you learn at that college anyhow? Think more in terms of Beowulf, composed in the mid 500s AD; it's still pretty much the same today as it was at its inception. Are you fucking kidding me? Hercules... Ever heard the name? He was a Greek demi-god. His real name was actually Herakles. His stories were passed on by oral tradition, and there are a multitude of variations. The same is true of the Beowulf saga. There are many different tellings and interpretations. Not to mention the fact that in some languages just a slight variation in inflection can change the whole meaning. It's even true in the English language. For instance, "What the fuck!?!?!?!," and "What the fuck." Not only that, but given the time frame involved, there is no possible way you could know that the story hadn't changed in drastic ways, building the legend till it was super human in scope and scale. There are actually a few good pro-Christian movies that have been released. You won't find them in theaters, of course. They used to release them as blockbusters back in Hollywood's hey day. The Ten Commandments? Ben Hur? The Robe? All blockbusters from the old days. In recent years, Passion of the Christ was very powerful (and also a blockbuster). More recently: The Bible (History Channel series) was excellently done, where Son of God was brought to the theater (taken from The Bible). Both were hits. The latest two hits were God is Not Dead and Heaven is for Real. They were both done very well. Kirk Cameron, unfortunately, produces very cheesy films. I've watched a couple of them and they're actually pretty embarrassing. After getting through them, you want to say "that wasn't so bad," but you end up saying "why the hell do they make these things so damn cheesy?" Whoever produced God is Not Dead and Heaven is for Real, however, were on the right track. Less cheese, less in your face messaging - just a good wholesome movie about the impact of Christianity. I find it funny, though, that atheists have decided to capitalize on Judeo-Christian themed movies. First, it was Noah... then Unbroken, and now Exodus. I guess they don't hate religion enough to cease capitalizing on them.

commentText: I'm so sick of people like Kirk Cameron claiming that Christmas has been "hijacked." People like him remind me of whiny little kids who throw tantrums when they have to share something they want all for themselves. "No! Christmas is about Jesus! I don't wanna say Happy Holidays! I want everyone else to celebrate Christmas MY way!" First of all, we encourage people to say Happy Holidays instead of Merry Christmas because guess what... not everyone celebrates Christmas! There are numerous holidays that are celebrated during the Winter Solstice that get forgotten because Christmas has pretty much taken over the holiday season. While I understand and appreciate the sentiment of someone saying "Merry Christmas," I think it's better to be all-inclusive when celebrating the holidays. Don't just assume everyone is celebrating Christmas. Second, if anything has been hijacked, it's the various celebrations that take place on/near the Winter Solstice that people like Kirk Cameron feel completely entitled to because of Christian privilege. Let people celebrate Christmas however the hell they want to. If you don't like it, too bad. Feel free to celebrate Christmas with Jesus and all the other Christian traditions. No one is stopping you! But please, if other people are happier and more comfortable celebrating Christmas with Santa Claus, Christmas trees, eggnog, and not Jesus, LET THEM. This is a secular country, so stop trying to force your religion on everyone else by making them celebrate Christmas the way you want them to. Bottom line: nobody "needs" Christ to celebrate Christmas and Christmas has not been "hijacked."
